awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Using Human-Centered Design to Conceptualize and Prototype Ways to Increase Graduate Student Engagement with Transformative Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The engineering and engineering education community is intensely interested in generating trained engineers who can address large scale, "important" problems. Such challenges rarely adhere to traditional boundaries, yet graduate students are frequently admitted and trained with the primary intent of teaching them to be deeply focused on highly specific problem domains, with markedly less emphasis on breadth, creativity and curiosity. This project seeks to explore the hypothesis that graduate engineering programs suffer from a lack of potentially transformative and creative applicants. Individuals from all stages of the graduate student pipeline will be interviewed with the goal of identifying potential problems in attracting students to graduate research. Based on the findings from these investigations, novel strategies to remediate these problems will be designed and tested. This project has the potential to develop approaches to overcome barriers to retention of creative thinkers in graduate engineering studies. Given that the future engineering community is shaped, at least in part, by individual decisions to pursue or not to pursue graduate studies, this study could radically impact the engineering community and its potential for transformative research. Notably, interviews across a wide spectrum of racial, ethnic and socio-economic backgrounds may also provide insights into differential influences on the decision to engage with graduate education, and improve strategies for diversity and inclusion.

This study will use a human-centered design approach, Design Thinking, to explore the question of how to increase graduate student engagement in transformative engineering research. A central tenet of the Design Thinking approach is that one must listen closely to and understand "users" before designing or implementing solutions to their needs or wants. Therefore, participants at all stages of the graduate student pipeline (undergraduates, graduates, faculty, administrators) will be interviewed using a framework of ethnographic techniques to understand whether potentially transformative students select out of the admissions process, and if so why. Additionally, the graduate admissions process and engineering education will be examined for their propensity to encourage or discourage creativity, intellectual curiosity, interdisciplinary perspectives, and a focus on large-scale important problems. Knowledge gained in these investigations will be used to develop prototypes to attract and retain potentially transformative thinkers, as well as to reframe first year graduate engineering curricula in order to stimulate creativity and interdisciplinary thinking. The overall goal of this research is to develop approaches to stem the hypothesized loss of creative, interdisciplinary thinkers in graduate engineering studies by overcoming barriers to recruitment and retention.

por.por_cntn:
Providing a pipeline of talented and creative engineering researchers is central to addressing challenges such as climate change, food security, and energy independence. While U.S. graduate engineering programs are among the best in the world, there is the potential to increase their transformative capacity. Specifically, there is a pool of talented undergraduate students who “opt out” of further studies. Surprisingly, very little research into these students’ underlying reasons has been done. Because these students do not apply or do not accept admission offers, their motivations and concerns remain invisible to graduate programs. Using techniques from human-centered design, we focused on the experiences of such students and other key stakeholders (including administrators, faculty, and current graduate students). The information gathered during this first phase of work then informed a variety of exploratory prototypes which we used to address various facets of engineering graduate studies.  

We took certain aspects of the research ecosystem as fixed. Specifically, we assumed that technical skill and knowledge, sometimes referred to collectively as "rigor", is an essential element of transformative research. We further assumed that most high-impact research is likely to be inherently interdisciplinary, and finally, that most transformative research will require creative approaches to problem solving.

We interviewed 29 individuals, for a total of nearly 60 hours. While we expected the primary driver of student decisions to be financial, the interviews suggested there are obstacles to graduate studies well outside monetary incentives. Through the course of our conversations, five themes emerged:

  • Students experienced a lack of well-being and experienced low self-esteem. Almost all the students lamented a grueling workload and a lack of positive reinforcement in completing demanding and time-intensive studies. 
  • They shared a perceived lack of creative opportunities in the major – While almost every student engaged in some sort of creative activity outside school (e.g., music, dance, video creation, visual arts), almost none of them characterized their work within school as creative.
  • The graduate admissions process was perceived as a barrier to be overcome, reducing student interest in applying. Students found the process exhausting, a possible “hidden rules game”, and were uneasy and uncertain about asking faculty for recommendations, especially if they knew them solely through coursework. The process was described as focused almost entirely on a limited set of metrics, excluding student interests and intellectual desires.
  • There was a perceived lack of interdisciplinary opportunities in the field of engineering. Very few students could recall an example of interdisciplinary thinking or working as an element of engineering education. This was particularly striking because the students indicated that they valued such opportunities highly and considered such opportunities as drivers in their desired future work.
  • Graduate school seemed less supportive than industry. There was a large distinction between student attitudes about work in industry vs. academic settings. Students who had industrial or corporate internships noted that the mentoring in the industry settings was more intentional and better organized than what they received on campus, which often took the form of academic, i.e., coursework advising.

In response to these insights, we created a set of early-stage prototypes to explore intervention opportunities in the graduate admissions environment. We created experiential exercises and a set of exploratory games to heighten awareness of faculty, administrators, and prospective students, and to give us additional insights into the graduate engineering studies environment. Examples of experiential exercises included “Opportunity of a Lifetime”, a scenario-based game that challenges players to use insights from personal creative hobbies or passion project to apply for a seemingly unrelated fictional, highly technical job. The resulting discussion creates a model for aspects of student experience in applying to for graduate studies. We also developed a tabletop game, Engineering Dominos, that helps clarify and rank the attributes, skills, and behaviours that engineering faculty value in graduate assistants. An immersive scenario, Admissions Game, explores specific aspects of the engineering graduate admissions process, highlighting the potential distinction between what is measured and what is said to be valued. In a very different prototype, we developed a videogame and directed a team of graduate and undergraduate students to program, build, and test it. The result, Monsters of Engineering, uses the metaphor of a marooned alien to explore interdisciplinarity, mental health, and curiosity in engineering education.

For more details on the project and our findings, please visit the project website: https://www.germination-transform.com/.
